data.title: Led Zeppelin, Kidderminster
data.text:
The leader of Led Zeppelin was Jimmy Page, a prolific and very experienced session guitarist of the 1960s.

In 1968 Jimmy was a member of legendary R&B band, The Yardbirds, who were about to split up.

With a number of tour dates still to honour, and with the rest of the band already departed, Jimmy Page began recruiting new musicians.

John Paul Jones was another respected session man, bass player and musical arranger, and he contacted Page after reading a music press article about the new band.

Singer wanted

Several established vocalists were also asked to join, but all were busy.

One of them recommended Robert Plant, a powerful singer from Worcestershire, and Jimmy went to see him perform; he was immediately impressed.

Robert Plant recommended an ex-bandmate for the drumming duties - John Henry Bonham.

They started to write their own songs, and the band completed the old Yardbirds tour obligations as 'The New Yardbirds'.

Jimmy Page was then legally obliged to stop using this name and had to come up with another.

New band name

The year before he had played a session with his old friend Jeff Beck and other players, including The Who's Keith Moon and John Entwistle.

They enjoyed playing together and even discussed striking out as a new group, but decided that the idea would 'go over like a lead Zeppelin'.

The perfect name for a heavy-rock band, it was adjusted to 'Led Zeppelin' for correct pronunciation purposes.

So, at the end of 1968, the legend of Led Zeppelin began and the band toured for months on end, building a reputation for excellent live performances.

It's said they achieved new attendance records and touring standards.

Original line-up

Led Zeppelin were Jimmy Page (guitar), Robert Plant (vocals), John Paul Jones (bass, keyboards) and John Bonham (drums).

Robert Plant was born in West Bromwich but grew up in Kidderminster, and he still lives in the area.

John Bonham was born in Redditch; he died in 1980 and is buried at Cutnall Green.

Led Zep facts

The band first played in Scandinavia in July 1968 as The New Yardbirds.

Their first gig as Led Zeppelin was at Surrey University in October 1968.

The original line up played their last gig in Berlin during July 1980.

The three surviving members played together at the Live Aid concert in Philadelphia in July 1985.

Plant, Page and Jones also played with members of Aerosmith and Jason Bonham, John's son, when Led Zeppelin were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1995.

Led Zeppelin's "Stairway To Heaven" was never released as a single, but became the most played song in the history of American radio.
